code: @Manual{,   title = {rextor: Prepare WEXTOR Data Easily},   author = {Anni Tave Overlander},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://iscience-kn.github.io/rextor/}, }

title: Prepare WEXTOR Data Easily
text: rextor R package facilitate data preparation data collected WEXTOR. offers functions read data, help visualize data color themes scales can help show data light--dark color scheme, well helper function. , dinosaur Rex offer words wisdom advice.

title: Prepare WEXTOR Data Easily
text: can install development version rextor GitHub :

title: Prepare WEXTOR Data Easily
text: can ask Rex specific topics, t.tests ask specify exact type statistic looking . generally hard time, just ask Rex nothing particular give encouragement help try !
code: library(rextor)  set.seed(1) ask_rex() #> No worries, Rex got you!

title: Prepare WEXTOR Data Easily
text: yet familiar WEXTOR: online experiment building tool relies standards web-based experimentation methodological best practices. means, generating studies collect data easy analyzing data R might tricky. WEXTOR data comes specific csv^comma-separated-values format figuring properly read data R can difficult starting R journey. Luckily, rextor, reading data becomes easy well! use openly available data set personality data collected three different conditions^information data, see github.com/iscience-kn/BiFiX. automatically generated variable names ideal usage R, can also identify variable name starts “.wx.” names start instead “v_” “variable”. Another option remove prefixes altogether left just easily legible variable names, . way, data frame personality now nicely formatted useful variable names ready edited . example, recommend conducting dropout analysis routine part analyzing online data offer dropR package facilitate analyses!
code: raw_data <- read_WEXTOR("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/iscience-kn/BiFiX/refs/heads/main/data/BiFiX_data.csv",                          keep_validation = FALSE)  # personality <- namepref(raw_data, ".wx.", "v_") personality <- removepref(raw_data)

title: Ask Rex — ask_rex
text: function lets ask dino Rex help. can try ask specific functions topics just use function -motivational words encouragement. :)

title: Ask Rex — ask_rex
text: topic want know ; either leave blank motivation specify 'ttest', 'mean'... Input must quotes!

title: Ask Rex — ask_rex
text: Returns advice explanations R; sometimes Rex asks follow-questions

title: Ask Rex — ask_rex
code: # Get motivation ask_rex() #> You can ask Rex about 'ttest', 'mean'   # Get specific information ask_rex("mean") #> mean(x) or if there are missing values in your data try mean(x, na.rm = TRUE). ask_rex(topic = "ttest") #> Please enter the number of the type of t-test you would like to know more about - (1) one-sample t-test, #> (2) two-sample (independent) t-test or (3) paired (dependent) t-test.:  #> Maybe ask something else?

what: Add variable name prefix (with substitution) — namepref
title: Add variable name prefix (with substitution) — namepref
text: function strips old prefix variable names dataframe. adds new prefix old one changes dataframe's names new ones.

title: Add variable name prefix (with substitution) — namepref
Add variable name prefix (with substitution) — namepref
text: dataframe dataframe pref_old Old prefix character variables dataframe pref_new New prefix character replace old one

title: Add variable name prefix (with substitution) — namepref
text: Returns dataframe variables renamed start old prefix.

title: Add variable name prefix (with substitution) — namepref
code: bla <- tibble::tibble(x_ar = 1:5, y_ar = 6:10) blo <- namepref(bla, "x_", "z_") names(bla) #> [1] "x_ar" "y_ar" names(blo) #> [1] "z_ar" "y_ar"

title: Read WEXTOR Data — read_WEXTOR
text: function, can easily read WEXTOR generated data. default, exported "CSV" file, stands "comma-separated values". R many available options reading type data, can make hard navigate one use - especially beginners.

title: Read WEXTOR Data — read_WEXTOR
text: filepath Location WEXTOR CSV file computer. keep_validation validation variable WEXTOR kept? TRUE default.

title: Read WEXTOR Data — read_WEXTOR
text: WEXTOR data R data object.

title: Read WEXTOR Data — read_WEXTOR
text: read_WEXTOR() function, just need provide filepath, .e. location CSV data file downloaded WEXTOR. want, can already decided whether keep first column containing -called validation variable, . input, rextor keep variable . can explicitly set keep_validation FALSE like data neat need extra measure. usage explained examples using open source BiFiX data psychological Big Five personality traits. function prepares WEXTOR data readable R human. give original data also make start end time participation easier read work later (default, WEXTOR return values date time separately, cluttering dataset).

title: Read WEXTOR Data — read_WEXTOR
code: data <- read_WEXTOR("https://github.com/iscience-kn/BiFiX/raw/main/data/BiFiX_data.csv")  # If you don't need the validation variable, try data_noval <- read_WEXTOR("https://github.com/iscience-kn/BiFiX/raw/main/data/BiFiX_data.csv",                           keep_validation = FALSE)

what: Remove WEXTOR variable name prefixes (automatic) — removepref
title: Remove WEXTOR variable name prefixes (automatic) — removepref
text: function strips old prefix server variable names dataframe. identifies variables start ".wx.#." # stands number, simply ".wx." removes prefixes easily legible usable variable names data!

title: Remove WEXTOR variable name prefixes (automatic) — removepref
Remove WEXTOR variable name prefixes (automatic) — removepref
text: dataframe dataframe, usefully containing variables server prefix ".wx.#."

title: Remove WEXTOR variable name prefixes (automatic) — removepref
text: Returns dataframe variables renamed start old prefix.

title: Remove WEXTOR variable name prefixes (automatic) — removepref
code: bli <- tibble::tibble(.wx.1.ar = 1:5, y_ar = 6:10, .wx.z = 11:15) blu <- removepref(bli) names(bli) #> [1] ".wx.1.ar" "y_ar"     ".wx.z"    names(blu) #> [1] "ar"   "y_ar" "z"

what: Coloring Scale for Data Visualization — scale_rextor
title: Coloring Scale for Data Visualization — scale_rextor
text: scale versatile powerful. offers several color palettes choose automatically recognizes whether use discrete continuous scale depending data type mapping object. can also used color fill aesthetics defining aesthetic accordingly directly inside function!

title: Coloring Scale for Data Visualization — scale_rextor
Coloring Scale for Data Visualization — scale_rextor
text: pal Color palette. Use either numbers 1 X one names: 'arby', 'cute'... direction Direction color palette. Keep blank use 1 default direction use -1 reverse colors. aesthetic aesthetic use scale ; either color fill, defaults color. ... common scale parameters.

title: Coloring Scale for Data Visualization — scale_rextor
text: ggplot plot object

title: Coloring Scale for Data Visualization — scale_rextor
code: library(ggplot2) ggplot(iris, aes(Species, Petal.Width, color = Petal.Width)) +  geom_jitter() +  theme_wob() +  scale_rextor()

what: Filter data frame by seriousness check — serious_check
title: Filter data frame by seriousness check — serious_check
text: Filter data frame item "seriousness check". data comes WEXTOR previous changes automatically created variable, able accept defaults function simply input data frame.

title: Filter data frame by seriousness check — serious_check
Filter data frame by seriousness check — serious_check
text: dataframe Data contains variable seriousness check. varname Variable seriousness check. Defaults "seriousness". keep Values variable keep. Defaults "participate"

title: Filter data frame by seriousness check — serious_check
text: Filtered data

title: Filter data frame by seriousness check — serious_check
Theme White on Black — theme_wob
text: theme option built used ggplot2 plot. offers several options dark theme, .e. dark background light writing.

title: Theme White on Black — theme_wob
text: max_font_size Maximum font size, used plot title (font sizes automatically adjusted accordingly). contrast Character indicate choice color palette depending desired contrast. Defaults "high". one "max", "high", "medium", "low", "pink" "rex".

title: Theme White on Black — theme_wob
text: Plot theme.

title: Theme White on Black — theme_wob
code: # Load the data data <- read_WEXTOR("https://github.com/iscience-kn/BiFiX/raw/main/data/BiFiX_data.csv")  # Create any plot library(ggplot2) ggplot(data, aes(age, color = gender, fill = gender)) +    geom_density(alpha = .5) +    theme_wob(contrast = "rex") #> Warning: Removed 272 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_density()`).
